title: Incommon
description:
I have long wanted to recreate the game Compatibility for the web because I love that game, and I thought there were ways to make it even more fun. Without the limitations of a physical board, you could see not only whether you were compatible with your partner, but you could see how much everyone has in common with everyone else. On top of that, we could play around with creating whatever categories and decks that you want.

I also decided I wanted to make this work like a Jackbox game. I had already done something like this with List List Ear, but I wasn't quite as satisfied with how that turned out. It got too buggy, and I never took the time to refactor it. It also didn't have a deck of cards with images, so I don't think it was as fun because of that.

One of the things I am most proud of with this game is how intuitive and smooth the actual swiping of the cards works. I spent quite a long time perfecting that so that it works on a phone, and I'm happy that with a bunch of friends and family playing it, that part worked well.

I also decided I would heavily use AI for this game, so it helped me with quite a bit of the code. That was fun, and it also helped me to better understand the current limitations and sweet spots of the current batch of LLMs. I tried Chat GPT, Gemini, and Claude. In the end, I stuck with Chat GPT.

title: Tetris
description: I watched the Tetris movie, and I got inspired to make it myself. I wanted to see if I could do it in one night. I sort of did. I got the basics working, but then there were some edge cases like moving the pieces once they landed and rotating them when they are close to the edge of the screen.

title: Roku Screensaver
description: This is a bit silly. I was watching the Roku screensaver, and Lucy and I were talking about how it worked, and then of course it made me want to make it, and so I did. It's not perfect, but close enough.

title: Spelling Bee
description:
After I did Wordle, I set my sights on Spelling Bee. I figured it would be a bit harder, but I clearly underestimated. My intuitions failed me as it was about 10x harder. One of the challenging parts that I had not considered when I first thought of the challenge was the actual creation of the words themselves to choose from so that there would always be at least one pangram.

I went a bit overboard with this one and decided to make it look as close to the original as possible just for fun. Then I added the other parts of the game where you can see the rankings and the current words you chose.

Finally, I decided to use local storage to keep track of the specific puzzle you were solving in case you wanted to share it.

title: Wordle
description: I did this mostly while on vacation in Asheville, NC. I wanted to see if I could make Wordle in a few hours, and I was able to successfully. Again, not perfect, but the basics of the game all worked. I then spent another day polishing it a bit, and then I lost interest. I tried to see what a length of 6 letters would do, and it was not very interesting. But, it was a fun little challenge.

title: Three Body
description:
I started reading the Three Body Problem, and the subject behind the title of the book piqued my interest. It is about how a three-body system is unstable and cannot be "solved". Frankly, I still don't really understand what that all means, but I decided this would be the perfect excuse to create a little space gravity simulation.

One fun thing with this project is it made me think about the project my dad made with orbiting bodies when I was a kid. It was actually one of the things that really made me think that programming could be creative and fun.

As with all of my projects, this was done in 2D, but I think it gets the point across. I had a lot of fun playing around with the randomly created bodies and seeing how they interacted with each other. I then created replicas of our Earth and moon, and then my favorite thing was creating a model of a solar system forming where the bodies crash into each other to create larger objects until you are left with a sun and a handful of planets.

I am well aware that this is a super primitive model that likely has many issues, but I still think it gets the point across and it's fun to watch.

title: Alphabear Solver
description: When April and I were on an Alphabear kick earlier in the pandemic, I created a quick JavaScript helper program to find really long words with existing letters that would preference letters based on points. I knew it was cheating, but I wanted to see how far I could take it.

title: MandelbART
description: Something made me get back into the Mandelbrot fractal, and as a challenge to myself, I wanted to see if I could generate the fractal based solely on the math formula myself without looking it up. I was successful, and then I decided I wanted to be able to play around with color palettes and allow the ability to download images of arbitrary sizes. Really happy with how it turned out. I still need to create a large print of an area and hang it in the room I'm currently in!

title: Langton’s Ant
description: I was on a cellular automata kick, and this was just too interesting not to make myself. I also wanted to play around with all of the different left-right patterns. This was fun, but not a major project. I did like the zoom and speed options I added.

title: Growing Snowflakes
description: After failing to create nice snowflakes for my falling snow program, I decided to challenge myself to create ones by mimicking the way snowflakes are actually created—by growing them using cellular automata. I feel like I got kind of close here. Some of the snowflakes do really look "snowflake-like" but not quite there. I ran into performance issues at the end, which is a common pattern for many of my projects.

title: List List Ear
description: This was my attempt at making my own version of a Jackbox game. I think I was kind of successful. I think this was my first go with React and also using Firebase. We did play it a few times with friends, and it worked and was fun, but also really buggy and the code was pretty unstable. If I wanted to improve on it at this point, I would definitely start from scratch.

title: Marathon Time Predictor
description: This was my capstone project as part of my machine learning nanodegree. Sourcing the data by scraping Garmin was actually the harder part here, and ultimately the weak link in the project. I tried a few different models but ended with gradient boosting. Another big challenge was cleaning up the data because people's Garmin logs are not always reliable. This project was pretty good, and I was successful in doing better than regular marathon predictors online based on Riegel's formula, but that's a low bar. But really, this project meant that I successfully completed my nanodegree, and that is something I'm really proud of because it was really time-consuming, but I learned a lot.

title: Ragnar Legs Calculator
description: This was a super quick, couple-hour program to create a schedule for assigning runners to Ragnar legs as evenly as possible. I'm pretty sure we ended up using it for Seattle. So that's pretty cool.

title: Falling Snow
description: I made this specifically for Hour of Code at Lucy's school. I think it came out pretty well as a teaching tool, and the kids were excited and had fun messing with the program. I made different versions adding to it by first starting with a single white dot on a black background. The program itself is fairly simple but quite effective at looking like snow. I especially like the jitter effect so the snowflakes aren't just falling straight down.

title: Superset
description:
I wanted to make a mobile game, and unlike before with Go Words Go where I started it as a web game for a mobile device, I wanted this to end up as an app for both iOS and Android. This was before React Native was a thing, so for a web developer, this was the best approach, and using AngularJS with Ionic made it a lot easier. There were a couple of really difficult moments while making this.

The first was the recursive function I wanted to create that generated all of the various Set decks. For whatever reason, I just could not break it down in my head and figure it out. I almost gave up on it and was going to manually create them separately. It wouldn't have even been that big a deal, but it bothered me knowing there was a better approach, and I couldn't do it. I remember using paper and pencil in a notebook to help me reason around it, and I finally figured it out. I'm sure this would have been no problem for someone more experienced than me with algorithms, but I remember being proud of myself when I figured it out.

The second was just dealing with the iOS and Android ecosystems for developing, bundling, and deploying these things out to the stores. What a pain in the butt. That was just challenging in being annoying and not clear, but I pushed my way through it.

My goal going into this was that at least one person downloaded this game that I didn't personally know. In the end, I don't even recall how many people downloaded it (it was free), but I was pleased when I got a cease and desist from the makers of Set. Somehow it got to them, and then I had to take it down.
